attributes.title: Charitable Giving: A Closer Look at Two Psychological Mechanisms

q1.value: Charitable Giving: A Closer Look at Two Psychological Mechanisms

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: What psychological mechanisms spur individuals’ willingness to donate toward a social cause? We implement a natural field experiment with one of the world’s largest NGOs, varying whether postal districts are exposed to Facebook video ads or not. The videos are specifically designed to either activate feelings of empathy or empowerment. Our outcome are donations as well as clicks on the ads, both aggregated at the postal district level. This pre-analysis plan briefly outlines the analyses we plan to conduct, honing in on our sampling, measurement and estimation strategy.

q16.value: The ads increase donations The empathy ads raise donations more than the empowerment ads

q17.value: Our primary outcome measure are donations.

registration_responses.q1: Charitable Giving: A Closer Look at Two Psychological Mechanisms
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to realization of outcomes
registration_responses.q15: What psychological mechanisms spur individuals’ willingness to donate toward a social cause? We implement a natural field experiment with one of the world’s largest NGOs, varying whether postal districts are exposed to Facebook video ads or not. The videos are specifically designed to either activate feelings of empathy or empowerment. Our outcome are donations as well as clicks on the ads, both aggregated at the postal district level. This pre-analysis plan briefly outlines the analyses we plan to conduct, honing in on our sampling, measurement and estimation strategy.

attributes.title: Behavioral effects of descriptive representation -- Lab edition

q1.value: Behavioral effects of descriptive representation -- Lab edition

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: How can diverse societies guarantee inclusiveness? Descriptive representation – that is, whether an individual shares a social characteristic with her elected representative – is advocated as an effective part of the solution. It has been shown to foster political stability, trust, participation, and efficacy, particularly among groups that have been historically marginalized (Gay, 2002; Mansbridge, 1999; Schwindt- Bayer and Mishler, 2005; West, 2017). The effects of descriptive representation have been said to go beyond the political realm and may empower disadvantaged social groups in all aspects of life. Empowerment arises with the existence of role models, a change in the level of expected discrimination, and altered beliefs about how much governmental institutions enforce anti-discrimination policies (among others, Marx, Ko and Friedman (2009)). Our study (1) experimentally varies whether women’s descriptive representation in national parliaments around the world is framed as positive achievement (positive frame treatment) or reason for concern (negative frame treatment) or not at all (no frame treatment) and, then, in a laboratory experiment, (2) elicits subjects’ willingness to complete a math task or a clerical task (i.e., subjects are asked to either complete additions for 5 minutes or type a sequence of characters), their beliefs about their relative performance in that task, their willingness to complete the task in a competitive environment (i.e., compete for a lower bonus with 2 other subjects or for a higher bonus with 3 other subjects) , and their willingness to work more (i.e., complete the task for 10 instead of 5 minutes).

q16.value: Main hypotheses: (1a) We predict an increase of women’s preference for completing the math task when receiving the positive frame treatment over negative frame and no frame treatments. We further expect (1b) women’s preference for the more competitive and (1c) the longer task to increase as well. For men, we expect a decrease in preferences for these kinds of tasks in the positive frame over the negative and no frame treatments (H2a-c). Equivalent to these hypotheses, we expect an increase in women’s performance in the math task, the more competitive task (conditional on choosing more competition), and in the longer task (conditional on choosing a longer task) in the positive frame treatment over negative and no frame treatments (i.e. overcoming stereotype threat) (H3). Finally, we expect an decrease in women’s belief that they are likely to be discriminated against, and only a slight increase (magnitude less than discrimination belief) in their beliefs about their relative performance (H4). Heterogeneous treatment effects: Treatment effects (on men and women) are expected to vary with subjects’ gender identification, gender role models, collective self-esteem, and beliefs in gender group marginalisation. Mechanism: The effects of the positive frame treatment on women will run through either of the following mechanism: Increased self-efficacy, increased self-esteem, decreased expectation of discrimination, or increased presence of female role models.

q17.value: Upon entering the laboratory, subjects answer a range of socio-demographic questions (including gender) and political attitudes questions, and are then randomly assigned to the positive frame, negative frame, or no frame treatments (random assignment blocked on gender). Subjects in the no frame treatment advance directly to a series of three tasks while we elicit from subjects in the positive/negative frame treatment further self-reported measures on subjects’ beliefs about gender identification, gender role models, collective self-esteem, and gender group marginalisation (moderator variables) as well as about self-efficacy, expected discrimination in society, role models, and self-esteem (Mediator/Mechanism) variables. The treatment screen (positive/negative frame) is shown between moderator and mediator variables. We recruit women and men from the subject pool at a ratio of 2:1. After the survey, subjects in the positive/negative frame treatment advance to the series of three tasks. Conversely, subjects in the “no frame” condition take the survey after they complete those three tasks (so as not to prime them). The three tasks are monetized and contain (1) adding numbers or typing strings of 4 random characters (subjects choose which task to complete, main outcome measure 1), (2) competing in a randomly chosen task against other participants (math or typing) for an additional bonus (subjects choose whether they want to compete for fewer tokens with 1 other participant or for more tokens with 2 other participants), and (3) completing a randomly chosen task (math or typing) for a certain period of time (subjects choose whether they want to complete the task for 5 or 10 minutes). Subjects receive 1 token for each correctly added number or correctly typed sequence of characters. We also elicit their belief about the percentage of other participants who scored lower than they did (outcome measure 2) and look at their score (outcome measure 3). The average treatment effect of the positive frame treatment is evaluated by a difference-in-means (choice math vs typing task) and difference-in-distribution tests (performance, belief about relative performance) as well as appropriate regression models which include moderator, mediator, and order of task variables.

attributes.title: The Political and Economic Targeting of Development Aid: A Field Experiment among Elected Officials in Malawi

q1.value: The Political and Economic Targeting of Development Aid: A Field Experiment among Elected Officials in Malawi

q2.value: Brigitte Seim | Ryan Jablonski | Johan Ahlback

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Development interventions often assume funds and materials will be allocated in accordance with need. In practice, such efficient targeting outcomes are rarely achieved. Government officials are the middlemen in many development projects, allocating foreign aid to organizations, facilities, and individuals in their communities. However, these officials sometimes have political incentives that conflict with development goals, such as the need to cull favour with critical groups of voters and the desire to claim credit for visible development projects. The tension is particularly poignant in Malawi, where foreign development aid constitutes a large portion of the national budget and decentralization leaves district officials in charge of managing it. In order to evaluate how elected officials make decisions about targeting development aid in Malawi, we conducted a series of experiments among councillors and MPs in Malawi. In partnership with a local NGO, we provide elected councillors and members of parliament in Malawi with the opportunity to decide which school in her ward should receive development materials . In order to evaluate how officials make these decisions, we randomly assigned the availability of information and the transparency associated with the allocation decision. The randomly assigned treatments in this experiment are designed to be low-cost adjustments to the aid allocation process, so that this experiment can practically inform development interventions in Malawi and elsewhere.

registration_responses.q1: The Political and Economic Targeting of Development Aid: A Field Experiment among Elected Officials in Malawi
registration_responses.q2: Brigitte Seim | Ryan Jablonski | Johan Ahlback
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

attributes.title: Preferences for the Political Future of Catalonia

q1.value: Preferences for the Political Future of Catalonia

q2.value: Laia Balcells | Jose Fernandez-Albertos | Alexander Kuo

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: How do citizens in democracies react when deep conflicts concerning national identities and the legitimacy of the existing constitutional order escalate? To what extent do the economic and social costs of conflict in these contexts act as a constraint on the polarization dynamics that can occur in these situations? Do these dynamics and perceived costs of conflicts affect public opinion views towards possible solutions to these conflicts? We address these questions in the context of the Catalonia region of Spain, which experienced a deep political crisis in the last months of 2017 that involved a secessionist drive from its regional government and a corresponding seizure of power of the regional government by the central government. We generate a set of hypotheses regarding preferences for citizen views on the actions that both regional and central governments should take to resolve the political situation, and hypothesize that such preferences are sensitive to economic and social costs of such actions. To test these hypotheses, we fielded a survey in Catalonia with some embedded experiments in the survey instrument just before the extremely politically salient 2017 regional elections. In the attached pre-analysis plan, we detail the survey instrument and the analyses that we will undertake once the data is received.

q16.value: We will test hypotheses regarding the determinants of preferences for the political future of Catalonia, and we do so by collecting data in the run-up of the regional elections in Catalonia. We test some hypotheses by embedding several survey experiments in the survey, which are discussed in the attached PAP. Our main set of hypotheses are that treatments that make costs of various polices salient should have effects on preferences for the political future of Catalonia, and that various of these treatments have greater effects for those with strong Catalan identity or previous activism on the issue than others. We also test some of the hypotheses with observational analyses. The main set of hypotheses are that those with stronger Catalan identity or previous activism on the issue will have different political preferences than other citizens. All the hypotheses to be tested are detailed in the PAP.

q17.value: The experimental hypotheses will be tested with differences-in means analyses and with regression analyses allowing us to compare treatment and control group(s). For a number of observational hypotheses, we will test them with standard multivariate analyses. See the attached PAP for methodological details on each of the tests that we plan to conduct.

q2.value: Mario Callegaro | Douglas Rivers | Norbert Schwarz

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: This is an an experiment to measure context effects in survey questionnaires, where responses potentially vary according to the order in which questions are asked.

q16.value: Three contexts (Contexts, Hollywood, Politics) will be assigned (with Control split into two groups, depending upon subsequent question order). Democrats are expected to consider sexual harassment more serious a problem in the political context than in the Hollywood or Control contexts, while Republicans are more likely to consider sexual harassment a serious problem in the Hollywood context, than in the Political or Control contexts. An interaction is also hypothesized.

registration_responses.q2: Mario Callegaro | Douglas Rivers | Norbert Schwarz
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: This is an an experiment to measure context effects in survey questionnaires, where responses potentially vary according to the order in which questions are asked.

Democrats are expected to consider sexual harassment more serious a problem in the political context than in the Hollywood or Control contexts, while Republicans are more likely to consider sexual harassment a serious problem in the Hollywood context, than in the Political or Control contexts. An interaction is also hypothesized.

attributes.title: Scaling Bayesian Probabilistic Record Linkage with Post-Hoc Blocking: An Application to the California Great Registers

q1.value: Scaling Bayesian Probabilistic Record Linkage with Post-Hoc Blocking: An Application to the California Great Registers

q2.value: Brendan S. McVeigh | Bradley Spahn | Jared S. Murray

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: We implement a Bayesian Record Linkage Algorithm described in our paper. This pre-registration is for the hand-coding of the correctness of linkages. We seek to compare our record linkage algorithm to fastLink, a software package developed by Enamorado et al. We split our sample into two categories, movers and non-movers, and draw a stratified sample from the movers and non-movers groups as follows: 150 linkages made only by fastLink (i.e. the Bayesian algorithm’s probability of the linkage being correct was less than or equal to .5, while fastLink returned a probability greater than.9) 150 linkages made only by the Bayesian algorithm (i.e. fastLink’s probability of the linkage being correct was less than or equal to .9, while the Bayesian algorithm returned a probability greater than .5) 100 linkages returned by both (with probability greater than .9 for fastLink and greater than .5 for the bayesian algorithm). The researchers then hand-code the linkages, marking them as correct, incorrect, or ambiguous.

q16.value: We seek to test whether the Bayesian algorithm made a higher proportion of correct matches, testing movers and non-movers separately. We will drop the ambiguous cases from the analysis.`

q17.value: a test of a difference in proportions conducted at the .05 significance level.

attributes.title: Ethnicity, Status, and Day-to-Day Discrimination: Evidence from the Field

q1.value: Ethnicity, Status, and Day-to-Day Discrimination: Evidence from the Field

q2.value: Nan Zhang | Delia Baldassarri | Johanna Gereke | Max Schaub

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Many studies of discrimination against immigrants and ethnic minorities in Western societies focus on differential access to employment, housing and institutional services (e.g. health care). However, relatively little research has examined ethnic minorities’ experiences with “day-to-day” discrimination – e.g. receiving poor service in stores and restaurants, being targeted for racist jokes, and other common discourtesies. Such day-to-day experiences of discrimination are important in that they can impact minorities’ emotional and mental well-being, as well as shape their attachment to the host society and their prospects for successful integration. Accordingly, the present study seeks to understand the extent and causes of day-to-day ethnic discrimination faced by various ethnic minorities in Milan, Italy. In doing so, we take account of the fact that ethnic minorities in Western societies tend to be poorer, on average, than members of the majority native population. Since poorer individuals (of any ethnicity) are treated with less respect and greater discourtesy, minorities’ experiences of discrimination may to a large extent reflect their (assumed) lower position in the economic hierarchy, rather than specifically racial or ethnic animus. Thus, a secondary rationale of the present study is to disentangle the economic versus ethnic factors underlying disparate treatment in native-minority encounters.

q16.value: Our study aims to address the following questions: (1) To what extent are different ethnic minorities in Milan subject to common discourtesies in their day-to-day interactions? (2) Can varying levels of discrimination be explained by natives’ stereotyped ranking of ethnic groups in terms of (socio-economic) status? (3) Holding status constant, how much “residual” discrimination is faced by various minority groups?

q17.value: Our research design adapts an established field experimental procedure for measuring respect / discourtesy in interpersonal encounters. Specifically, we measure the frequency by which cars yield to pedestrians at zebra crossings. By varying pedestrians’ ethnicity and dress (as a signal of economic status) and comparing the “yield rate” across various treatment conditions, we will be able to gage both the level of “minor” discrimination faced by individuals from different ethnic groups, as well as the extent to which this discrimination is driven by perceptions of economic status. The experiment will proceed in two phases. In Phase 1, we aim to recruit ordinary passersby in multi-ethnic neighborhoods in Milan to serve as a our Crosswalk participants. In this way, we can assess drivers’ reactions to individuals as they are “naturally dressed” in order to capture a baseline level of discrimination. In Phase 2, we will hire both minority and native Italian actors to repeat the Phase 1 study, but dressed as either a “neutral” or “rich” person. By controlling pedestrians’ attire, Phase 2 will allow us to disentangle the economic vs. ethnic motives behind the behavior we observe in Phase 1.

attributes.title: Mobile Technology and Civic Engagement: A Downstream Experiment on the Effect of Phone Ownership and Encouragement Messages on Local Civic Participation

q1.value: Mobile Technology and Civic Engagement: A Downstream Experiment on the Effect of Phone Ownership and Encouragement Messages on Local Civic Participation

q2.value: Philip Roessler | Peter Carroll | Daniel Nielson

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: What is the effect of mobile phone ownership on civic and political engagement? With the spread of low-cost hand-held phones to all corners of the globe, the impact of the mobile technology revolution on politics is of great importance. Existing observational studies generally find a positive association between mobile communication and civic and political participation (Campbell and Kwak 2010; Lee et al. 2014), including on violent and non-violent mobilization (Pierskalla and Hollenbach 2013; Manacorda and Tesei 2016). There have been fewer experimental studies, however, on the effect of mobile phone ownership on political engagement. Those studies that have been undertaken focus almost exclusively on the effect of Short Message Service (SMS) texts, or text messages, on inducing voter turnout (Dale and Strauss 2009; Malhotra et al. 2011), shaping vote choice (Buntaine, Bush, Jablonski, Nielson, and Pickering 2016) and eliciting citizen feedback (Grossman et al. 2015a; Grossman et al. 2015b). As a cheap and efficient means to disseminate information in bulk, mobile messaging has been embraced by international organizations, non-governmental organizations, governments and private corporations to reach out to a large number of end-users. In the political realm, this transformation in the intensity and extensity of information exchange between citizens and their governments, especially in non-democratic states where such linkages are traditionally weak, may help to strengthen the citizen-government feedback loop that underpins political accountability (Bailur and Gigler 2014). However, existing experimental research probing the effects of mobile-based informational campaigns on political or civic engagement rarely takes into consideration the mediating effects phone ownership may have. Who holds the phone likely affects who receives information and ultimately who participates in political and civic life. This matters because critical disparities in mobile phone ownership exist both across society and within households. According to existing research, women are 14 percent less likely to own a mobile phone than men in low or middle-income countries (GSMA 2015). The gap is even starker among rural women or between literate and illiterate individuals. One broader implication of this digital divide is informational campaigns designed to empower citizens and improve political accountability may be further marginalizing the marginalized and reinforcing or even worsening social inequality. This study represents the first field experiment to examine the effect of heterogeneous phone ownership on the efficacy of a mobile technology-based informational campaign on inducing civic engagement. It piggy-backs on an existing large-scale field experiment supported by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation that examined the impact of mobile phone ownership on the uptake and usage of digital financial services (Roessler, Myamba, Carroll, and Nielson 2017). It represents a unique opportunity to better understand how mobile phone ownership affects civic engagement through the mechanism of women’s empowerment. We test the impact of mobile phone ownership on civic engagement in the context of a land rights training workshop held by the Tanzanian non-governmental organization, HAKIARDHI. A training workshop on land rights and land tenure makes a good test of direct mobile communication on female civic engagement as prevailing patriarchal norms and interests may affect women’s ability to learn about such opportunities. While formally women’s right to own and inherit land is safeguarded by the 1999 Tanzanian Land Act, in many communities customary practices based on patrilineal principles continue to prevail. Thus, in the case of divorce or death of their husbands women are often denied from inheriting land (Duncan 2015). As a land rights advocacy organization, HAKIARDHI holds a number of training workshops, including those for women to educate them about their legal protections and how to act on their rights. Based on our past work in Tanzania, there is a demand among women for this type of information. Among a similar sample of Tanzanian women, more than 80% of respondents viewed lack of equal rights to own and inherit land as an important issue women in Tanzania face and nearly 90% of the participants said they would be interested in attending a workshop to learn more about land and inheritance rights for women (Roessler, Myamba, Carroll and Nielson 2016).

q16.value: Our primary hypothesis is that mobile phone ownership increases civic engagement. Specifically, we hypothesize that those who have owned their for over a year will be more likely to attend the workshop than those who have recently received their phones. We also hypothesize that subjects who received a smart phone will be more likely to attend than those who (1) had a basic phone at the start of study (Experiment 2 control) or (2) received a basic phone at the start of the study (Experiment 1 basic phone group). As phone ownership may also increase economic and income-generating opportunities, phone owners may also face higher opportunity costs to participate in the workshops. But given the salience of this issue among women (based on self-reported information from our participants on important issues facing women), we expect the efficacy mechanism to trump the opportunity cost mechanism. Our secondary hypothesis is that those who receive the economic and gender equality encouragement messages will be more likely to attend the training than those who receive an encouragement absent of these topic specific encouragements. We also expect interaction effects between phone treatments and the messages given the increased economic well-being and empowerment that comes from phone ownership, which we expect to be activated by the messages. In addition to testing the effect of personal phone ownership on civic engagement, in this study we are also able to probe the mechanisms of such an effect. Mobile phone ownership can affect civic engagement through two channels: an information mechanism and an empowerment mechanism. As everyone will have a mobile phone and receive the same information, this study will allow us to eliminate the information mechanism and focus on the empowerment mechanism. Empowerment is broadly defined as “the expansion in people’s ability to make strategic life choices in a context where this ability was previously denied to them,” and attributes this to increased access to resources and agency. We expect that mobile phone ownership over the previous year engenders higher levels of agency and individual efficacy and these attributes will result in higher turnout to the workshop among the phone group recipients.

q17.value: This study represents the first-of-its-kind to experimentally test how owning a mobile phone affects civic engagement. Piggybacking on an existing Gates-funded field experiment on mobile technology and use of digital financial services that we are running among 2,000 women in Tanzania, we plan to leverage random variation in mobile phone ownership to test its effect on women's attendance in a workshop on women as drivers of economic development. The original study had two experiments in one: Experiment 1 included 1350 female non-phone owners with the following study groups: A. Basic Phone: 385 women received basic handsets B. Smartphone: 385 women received smartphones C. $20 Cash Transfer: 175 women received a small cash grant D. Control Group: 405 women were in the control group—and promised to receive a basic handset at endline Experiment 2 included 650 female phone owners with the following study groups: A. Smartphone: 280 women received basic handsets B. $60 Cash Transfer: 105 women received a small cash grant D. Control Group: 265 women were in the control group—and promised to receive a smartphone at endline This civic engagement study will come on the heels of the completion of the mobile phone study. At the end of the mobile phone study, all of the women in the control groups will receive mobile phones. For the civic engagement study, after distributing the basic phones and smartphones to the control group, we will invite all women to a workshop on land rights. All women will be invited via SMS. Thus everyone should be informed about the land rights workshop since at the time of the study everyone should have a phone. We will message participants through the following channels: 1.) the SIM card we gave them for the mobile phone experiment;2.) the best contact number to reach them, which we asked about at end of mobile phone experiment; 3.) the alternative contact persons through which participants said we could reach them. We will message through all of these channels to ensure that word gets out about the workshops to all participants, whether in treatment groups or control groups. The effect of sending messages of encouragement to promote some behavior has been well studied in other contexts (for full review see DellaVigna and Gentzkow 2010). In addition to our main source of exogenous variation in this study from the random assignment of phone ownership, we will also randomly vary the content of the invitation messages sent to study participants, contributing to this body of work on encouragement messaging. In a full factorial design, we will test whether messages that encourage participation, through either the priming of personal economic benefits or community-level wellbeing, increases interest in and attendance at workshops on a civic topic (compared to a control message without such priming). Our primary outcome measure is meeting attendance, which will be recorded by our field team during the workshops. We will also conduct a phone survey will all invitees following the workshops.

q27.value: Researchers, Innovations for Poverty Action - Tanzania

registration_responses.q1: Mobile Technology and Civic Engagement: A Downstream Experiment on the Effect of Phone Ownership and Encouragement Messages on Local Civic Participation
registration_responses.q2: Philip Roessler | Peter Carroll | Daniel Nielson
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: What is the effect of mobile phone ownership on civic and political engagement? With the spread of low-cost hand-held phones to all corners of the globe, the impact of the mobile technology revolution on politics is of great importance. Existing observational studies generally find a positive association between mobile communication and civic and political participation (Campbell and Kwak 2010; Lee et al. 2014), including on violent and non-violent mobilization (Pierskalla and Hollenbach 2013; Manacorda and Tesei 2016). There have been fewer experimental studies, however, on the effect of mobile phone ownership on political engagement. Those studies that have been undertaken focus almost exclusively on the effect of Short Message Service (SMS) texts, or text messages, on inducing voter turnout (Dale and Strauss 2009; Malhotra et al. 2011), shaping vote choice (Buntaine, Bush, Jablonski, Nielson, and Pickering 2016) and eliciting citizen feedback (Grossman et al. 2015a; Grossman et al. 2015b). As a cheap and efficient means to disseminate information in bulk, mobile messaging has been embraced by international organizations, non-governmental organizations, governments and private corporations to reach out to a large number of end-users. In the political realm, this transformation in the intensity and extensity of information exchange between citizens and their governments, especially in non-democratic states where such linkages are traditionally weak, may help to strengthen the citizen-government feedback loop that underpins political accountability (Bailur and Gigler 2014). However, existing experimental research probing the effects of mobile-based informational campaigns on political or civic engagement rarely takes into consideration the mediating effects phone ownership may have. Who holds the phone likely affects who receives information and ultimately who participates in political and civic life. This matters because critical disparities in mobile phone ownership exist both across society and within households. According to existing research, women are 14 percent less likely to own a mobile phone than men in low or middle-income countries (GSMA 2015). The gap is even starker among rural women or between literate and illiterate individuals. One broader implication of this digital divide is informational campaigns designed to empower citizens and improve political accountability may be further marginalizing the marginalized and reinforcing or even worsening social inequality. This study represents the first field experiment to examine the effect of heterogeneous phone ownership on the efficacy of a mobile technology-based informational campaign on inducing civic engagement. It piggy-backs on an existing large-scale field experiment supported by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation that examined the impact of mobile phone ownership on the uptake and usage of digital financial services (Roessler, Myamba, Carroll, and Nielson 2017). It represents a unique opportunity to better understand how mobile phone ownership affects civic engagement through the mechanism of women’s empowerment. We test the impact of mobile phone ownership on civic engagement in the context of a land rights training workshop held by the Tanzanian non-governmental organization, HAKIARDHI. A training workshop on land rights and land tenure makes a good test of direct mobile communication on female civic engagement as prevailing patriarchal norms and interests may affect women’s ability to learn about such opportunities. While formally women’s right to own and inherit land is safeguarded by the 1999 Tanzanian Land Act, in many communities customary practices based on patrilineal principles continue to prevail. Thus, in the case of divorce or death of their husbands women are often denied from inheriting land (Duncan 2015). As a land rights advocacy organization, HAKIARDHI holds a number of training workshops, including those for women to educate them about their legal protections and how to act on their rights. Based on our past work in Tanzania, there is a demand among women for this type of information. Among a similar sample of Tanzanian women, more than 80% of respondents viewed lack of equal rights to own and inherit land as an important issue women in Tanzania face and nearly 90% of the participants said they would be interested in attending a workshop to learn more about land and inheritance rights for women (Roessler, Myamba, Carroll and Nielson 2016).

But given the salience of this issue among women (based on self-reported information from our participants on important issues facing women), we expect the efficacy mechanism to trump the opportunity cost mechanism. attributes.title: Counterframes, Counterargument, and Confusion: Do Citizens Benefit from Hearing Both Sides?

q1.value: Counterframes, Counterargument, and Confusion: Do Citizens Benefit from Hearing Both Sides?

q2.value: Ryan Cotter | Milton Lodge | Robert Vidigal

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Experimental Frames Pro Frame There has been a lot of recent discussion about whether to allow drilling for oil and gas off the Atlantic Coast and in the eastern Gulf of Mexico. The main argument for those in favor of drilling is that drilling increases our oil supply, which leads to lower gas prices. It also generates employment opportunities and development.  Con Frame There has been a lot of recent discussion about whether to allow drilling for oil and gas off the Atlantic Coast and in the eastern Gulf of Mexico. The main argument for those opposed to drilling is that workers are required to learn new skills in order to protect themselves against the dangers of drilling. Marine life also must adapt to survive in the face of site construction and drilling. Counterframes (pro/con argument order randomized) There has been a lot of recent discussion about whether to allow drilling for oil and gas off the Atlantic Coast and in the eastern Gulf of Mexico. The main argument for those in favor of drilling is that drilling increases our oil supply, which leads to lower gas prices. It also generates employment opportunities and development. The main argument for those opposed to drilling is that workers are required to learn new skills in order to protect themselves against the dangers of drilling. Marine life also must adapt to survive in the face of site construction and drilling. Control (no frame)

q16.value: Affective Congruence Predictions The affective charge of an individual’s considerations will be highly congruent with subject’s attitude towards drilling. Tier 1 considerations will show greater congruence than tier 2 considerations. Those with strong attitudes will show greater congruence than those with weak or neutral attitudes. Weak attitudes predictions Individuals with weak prior attitudes exposed to a single frame will exhibit greater correspondence between their associations with drilling and the concepts mentioned in the treatment frame. Individuals with weak prior attitudes exposed to a counterframes will report more diffuse, less coherent associations with drilling. These individuals will also report greater issue confusion and attitude uncertainty than those exposed to a single frame. Motivated Reasoner Predictions Individuals with strong priors exposed to an attitudinally congruent frame will elaborate upon the concepts from the frame. Individual with strong priors exposed to an attitudinally incongruent frame will think of concepts that help them resist the incongruent frame. Individuals with strong priors exposed to counterframes will give greater attention towards resisting the incongruent frame than elaborating upon the congruent frame. Confusion and attitude certainty scores will be no different between those with strong attitudes exposed to a single frame and those exposed to the counterframes.

q17.value: Affective Congruence Analyses Create affective congruence measure = % of individual’s concepts that are the same directional affect as the individual’s drilling attitude Weight affect by centrality of the concept Compare within conditions to see if collapsing conditions is viable (ie: there should be no significant difference in the affective congruence measures between the Pro-Drilling X Strong Attitude X Pro Frame condition and the Anti-Drilling X Strong Attitude X Con Frame) Weak attitudes Analyses Create elaboration measure by calculating % mentioned concepts from the treatment frame in each of the naïve single frame conditions. Average across naïve single frame conditions. Repeat for the naïve dual frame conditions. Compare elaboration measure between naïve single frame condition and the naïve counterframe condition Aggregate associations into networks for the naïve single frame condition and the naïve counterframe conditions. Compare network coherence measures. Compare the various confusion and attitude certainty measures between the naïve single frame condition and the naïve counterframe condition. Also: See if subjects with no attitude regarding drilling are significantly different from those with weak attitudes. Compare the treatment group outcomes to those of the control group. Motivated Reasoner Analyses Create elaboration measure by calculating % mentioned concepts from the treatment frame in each of the MR single frame conditions. Average across MR single frame conditions. Repeat across MR counterframe conditions. Compare elaboration measure between MR single frame condition and MR dual frame condition. Aggregate associations into networks for the MR single frame conditions and the MR counterframe conditions. Compare network coherence measures. Compare the various confusion and attitude certainty measures between the MR single frame condition and the MR counterframe condition.
